null.title: Favorite Books to Gift For Baby
null.content:
As I await the birth of my sweet little nephew (even though we have a couple months left to go), I've been going a little overboard shopping for him! I think, for example. he may own every single bear themed outfit that exists thanks to my mom and me. He is also now the proud owner of a giant teddy bear (thanks to this favorite auntie).

The teacher in me always reaches for books as gifts for baby. In fact, I always try to bring a book or two anytime I attend a shower, so I thought I'd share some books I think make great gifts for a baby or baby shower!

  1. A book that matches the theme- This is not a specific book, but if you can find a board book with the nursery or shower theme, that's a really cute way to tie the theme in with the gift.
  2. A book that matches their name. When my niece Angelina was born, for the first few events in her life, I bought her the Angelina Ballerina books. My oldest has a book about Russell the Sheep. It's super fun if you can find something that has their name. There are also some DIY books that have the name in them.

Here are some of the more generic books I think make great baby shower gifts:

Love You Forever

Goodnight Moon

Animally

Cuddle Bear

Courduroy

Nursery Rhyme

I Wish You More

On the Night You Were Born

The Very Hungry Caterpillar

Wonky Donky

change-of-plans.name: change-of-plans
change-of-plans.title: Change. Of. Plans
change-of-plans.content:
I had a major wing it mom moment today. I'm realizing that consciously going with the flow helps me to get things done and keep my cool when situations don't go as planned!

Today I got all three kids packed up for a trip to Six Flags. We were all super psyched to go and I had finally convinced my husband, Russ, to go with us. We were running late, but I decided since our only goal was to be together as a family, I wasn't going to worry about it. We stopped for coffee and an egg wrap (even though I didn't need anything and we were running late).

As we were pulling out of the drive through line I heard that yucky, yet familiar noise followed by "Mom! She puked!"... For real?

Change of plans again.

We headed home to clean her up and knew it wasn't the right day for rides. The kids

am-i-a-wing-it-mom.name: am-i-a-wing-it-mom
am-i-a-wing-it-mom.title: Are You a Wing It Mom?
am-i-a-wing-it-mom.content: You may be wondering what what this blog is all about...  and what in the world a wing it mom is... You may even be asking "Am I a wing it mom?" Chances are the answer is yes. I'll try to provide you some answers while I sit in the glow of my laptop screen sitting on the toy cluttered floor of my 18 month old's room as she is finally dozing off... which is a form of paying my dues for stinking at sleep training. Life as moms means winging it... going with the flow... and feeling like you never quite have it all together! No fancy quizzes, no points to tally.... You are a wing it mom if you've ever found yourself in a situation similar to any of these: *Juggling three kids, you carry in three bags of groceries - and don't notice the bag of ice pops and lunch meat is still in your trunk hidden behind the stroller. *You let your kids play in the fountain at an amusement park in their regular clothes. They'll dry *shrug* *You sometimes sit in your recliner chair like a queen and admire the amount of devastation your children can invoke upon your kingdom in 10 short minutes. *Your neighbor shows up unannounced and says something like "So this is what a house looks like when you have three kids." *You open a package of crackers in the middle of the grocery store to keep your kids quiet. *You sometimes just put all the art supplies on the table and banish your children to the dining room "until they've made something awesome" because you just need a break. *You get all the way to the store and realize you haven't brushed your teeth... or hair. *On a trip to the dinosaur park  you realize you forgot the sippy cup... so you are the weird person asking for an empty cup and lid. *You are reading You are a Badass to your 18 month old as her bedtime story as she falls asleep because it's the only reading time you get. I may find myself adding to this list from time to time... but you get the gist!  If any of these scenarios sound like you, or things you've experiences I'm proud to anoint you a wing it mom! I hope you'll enjoy coming along this wing it mom journey with me! Itl'l be filled with stories, fun, ideas, learning ideas (especially for little ones) and of course wing it mom real moments! I promise to be real with you through the fun pinteresty posts that might find their way on here! To help get us started... share why you think you might be a wing it mom below!

5-quick-and-easy-bus-themed-activities-f.name: 5-quick-and-easy-bus-themed-activities-for-toddlers
5-quick-and-easy-bus-themed-activities-f.title: 5 Quick and Easy Bus Themed Activities for Toddlers
5-quick-and-easy-bus-themed-activities-f.content:
If your toddler is anything like mine, her attention span for a focused activity is about 3 minutes if it's a good day! My goal is to find fun thematic ways to help give my little gal a good background and the beginning learning skills with fun and hands on activities involving sensory play and exposing her to a number of different activities! These may seem sort of simple, but the goal is really to provide about 15 minutes to enrich her day in addition to our regular play, visits to the park, library story hour etc. The goal is just to talk about things, read stories, sing songs, and of course - make a mess! Talk about the colors, count when you can, and just get down and play with your little one! Most importantly, don't stop yourself from trying things that might be a little tough for your toddler! If you end up being the only one singing, or find yourself being the one sorting out the shapes, it's totally fine! You are showing your kiddo a great model of what these type of skills and activities look like! Big brothers went back to school this week, so it was a perfect time to kick our activities off with a school bus theme! Here are 5 quick and easy bus themed activities for your toddler at back to school time! Note: This post contains affiliate links. This means that by clicking on and purchasing these products, I make a small commission at no additional cost to you. As an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases.

Finger painting:

You can finger paint pretty much anything. Just observe your toddler with mashed potatoes at dinner. This activity encourages sensory exploration, color recognition and practice, and vocabulary development!   2. Happy Kids On the Bus- Draw kids on the bus, or place happy stickers on the bus photo. My little one is sticker crazy right now, so this one actually took quite a while... and many many stickers! This is a great tie in to emotions as well as a way to convince her that buses are not just evil yellow tornadoes coming to whisk her brothers away from her.  

Coloring-

Don't forget that good old fashioned coloring is a great way for your kiddo to express their creativity! This one I just give her the (washable) markers and let it go! This is also a great time to mention vocabulary related to parts of the bus (tire/ wheel, window, front, back) [caption id="attachment_64" align="aligncenter" width="560"] As you can see... this one has already found its way to our fridge.[/caption]

Wheels on the Bus-

Make balls/ tire shapes with black playdough- there is no room for professional detail here. Then match them to the wheels on the buses in the picture. Count as you go!

 

 Basic Sorting:

This kind of activity is awesome for really young kiddos! It helps them to develop categorizing and organizational skills. My 18 month old sorts about 4 at a time, and that's all her attention span can handle for now, but she loves it! And it is definitely helping to increase her vocabulary!   Don't forget pretend play! Use a play bus or cars to pretend play. We like to count to three and then roll the car back and forth, count the people figures we put inside, and even drive it down roads made with blocks or playdough (for our small toy car sized)

This is the bus toy that we have! Pink Lil' Movers School Bus Little People by Fisher-Price (Styles Vary) We also sing The Wheels on the Bus all week long. (She LOVES the "baby on the bus" part). Here are links to the 5 books that are also great to use during this week!       If you'd like to try any of these bus themed activities for your little one, here's a link to the PDF schedule and plans I created to share with you!   And... in case any of you are thinking "How is this 'winging it?"  Well moms, I put my pants on one leg at a time just like you.... I promised you real big messes, so, here is what my kitchen looked like on "Make Playdough" day... as my husband was making homemade chili from the garden, and Ellie entertained herself in the pot and pan cabinet... all in the middle of repainting our downstairs.... the winging it is alive and well! Not to worry :-)

what-are-you-reading-to-your-baby.name: what-are-you-reading-to-your-baby
what-are-you-reading-to-your-baby.title: What Are You Reading To Your Baby?
what-are-you-reading-to-your-baby.content: Hey! I just met you, and this is crazy... but what are you reading to your baby? I start off by placing this disclaimer right here.. I am a teacher by training and at heart. I have a Master's Degree in Remedial Reading and Language Arts... my undergrad studies are in English. It probably comes as no surprise to you that I was the kind of mom who packed a book in my hospital bag before having each of my babies and I read to them from the day they were born. When my babies were born, the days got busy and they looked like little squishy bundles who seemed to sleep, eat and cry. They certainly didn't seem to be paying attention to the books I was reading anyway. Why was it important to make reading part of our routine? The thing is that as moms we know that time escapes us... the little habits that fall out of our daily schedules often go by the wayside, and are even more difficult to reintroduce when the time is right. The fact is, if you stop reading to your baby, how will you know that it's the right day to start? I was so afraid I'd somehow forget to start reading, that I just started on day 1, and made sure we read every day from that point on. I also had this feeling that maybe they were listening. The truth of the matter is... your squishy little baby is listening, to every single thing you say (a lesson I learned the first time a four letter word came out of Rjs mouth). From the time they are born they are listening. They are watching and soaking in every word you say. Reading to your baby is a great calming and bonding experience, but also opens up huge opportunities for your baby to hear language and vocabulary and to just hear your voice! Whether it's luck or not, I've also grown 3  kids who LOVE to read... and when asked how I got them to be that way, I just can't help but attribute it to our every day reading! From the time they're super small, you're modeling that reading is a good, warm experience and can even be a social one. Before long you'll see him/her sitting on the floor flipping through, or chewing on their own little books as they explore reading themselves... or piling up all their books and flopping right into your lap "Mommy a boop"(as Ellie says when she wants to read). When you model being a reader for your child, and practice reading with them... I just believe they have a much greater chance of becoming independent and excited readers. So this leads us to the big question- what are you reading to your baby? I actually come from the camp that it doesn't really matter what you read, just that you read. Sure we have tons of board books around the house and we read them on repeat all.day.long... but the truth is her bedtime story is actually the only time of day I have to sneak in my reading in. I sit down next to her bed, hold her hand, and read to her. Currently we're reading "You are a Badass." Maybe some of the positive vibes from the book will float into her little head and she'll grow up knowing she can have all that she desires in this world. At very least, I'm reading and she's listening. Here's the takeaway, in case you're a busy mom looking to get the whole gist of the article in the last couple lines- Read to your baby (and kids)... model reading yourself because they are listening... even if you're reading "You are a Badass." Side note (And affiliate disclaimer: This is affiliate link. This means that by clicking on and purchasing these products, I make a small commission at no additional cost to you. As an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases. This book is absolutely amazing!

ive-always-wanted.name: ive-always-wanted
ive-always-wanted.title: I've always wanted...
ive-always-wanted.content: (This post contains affiliate links. This means that by clicking on and purchasing these products, I make a small commission at no additional cost to you. As an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases. I was looking out my kitchen window this morning thinking to myself "I have always wanted a yard with sunflowers." Then I started thinking about some of the other things I've always wanted...to have children and a family, to be a stay at home mom, to blog, to really help other people, to not worry what other people think. I realized in that moment that I have achieved almost all of these things. I have so so many things to be grateful for. Not just thankful, but truly deeply grateful. I've been doing tons of reading... right now I'm reading both You Are a Badass: How to Stop Doubting Your Greatness and Start Living an Awesome Life and listening to Girl, Wash Your Face: Stop Believing the Lies About Who You Are so You Can Become Who You Were Meant to Be... and one theme I hear repeated again and again is to live gratefully... even when your fridge is left open overnight right after you grocery shop and have to throw out all the dairy products- live gratefully... even when you go to the store to replace all the groceries and your car breaks down in the parking lot, thereby warming up all the repurchased dairy products- live gratefully (both of these things truly happened to me within the past 24 hours. Guess what? I have the means to repurchase the groceries, I have a husband to come jump start my car, the guy diagonally across from me in the packed parking lot pulled out just in time for my husband to pull in to jump start my car, I have three beautiful kids, I am a stay at home mom, I'm sitting here writing to you, and there are sunflowers in my yard. There are so so many things to be grateful for! Often we think of the things we want to have, or wish we had, or even things we think we'll never have. It's really easy to feel stressed rather than grateful in those moments... but here's what I am beginning to realize- I have a family because I work to create positive relationships, I am a stay at home mom because as a family we have set our selves up for this reality, I blog because I make the time, and I have sunflowers because we planted them. So this post is definitely a little bit of mushy gooshiness, but here's the busy mom takeaway: Live gratefully, and if you want sunflowers in your yard... plant them!

4-reasons-busy-moms-should-meal-plan.name: 4-reasons-busy-moms-should-meal-plan
4-reasons-busy-moms-should-meal-plan.title: 4 Reasons Busy Moms Should Meal Plan
4-reasons-busy-moms-should-meal-plan.content:
Hey! If you're anything like me the "What's for dinner?" question rings through the house day in and day out. Often times, I wasn't even sure what we were going to have. I read and watched as other awesome mamas were meal planning as a part of their nutrition regimen. I decided that it was time for me to give meal planning a try! Here are 4 of the perks of meal planning I've discovered along the way:

1. My family stopped bugging me!

When I started meal planning I had an answer to this question the first time it was asked. There was no longer a need for my family to put the question on repeat! The ways that I have meal planned have all also included posting the menu on the side of the fridge so I they can check themselves!

2.  I planned healthier meals

When I was sitting down on Sunday morning to plan the meals for the week, I am ambitious and excited about eating healthy meals all week long. I am much less likely to default to "let's get a pizza" or "It's getting late... We'll stop at Mickey D's".

3. I save money

When I sat down to plan meals,  I often did what I call "piggy bag planning". If I plan for tacos during the week, I'll use some sour cream for tacos, and the rest for a baked potato later in the week. If I add a sandwich that I want lettuce for, I also plan for salads so we use the entire head of lettuce.  Because of this we have much less waste in our home and spend less on groceries each week!

4. It saves time!

Knowing the kinds of meals we're going to be having gives me the opportunity activate some time saving powers. One example is, if I am chopping veggies for a salad, I'll take out and do some meal prep for the veggie flatbread pizzas we'll be having the next night.  The next night, when I'm ready for dinner, I wont need to get the cutting board out again, rinse, chop, clean up and then get the pizzas ready. Another example really engages in that "piggy back planning" that I mentioned before. If I make breaded eggplant sandwiches, I'll just cook the whole eggplant in slices the first night, even though we only need 4 or 5. Since the pan is already hot, the breading mess is already out, and I'm waiting for it to cook- I'll get a pan out, put some sauce in the bottom, and start preparing an eggplant parm dish for the next day. It takes a little bit more time the first night, but saves tons the next. It has definitely been a nice game changer for my family, and I've tried to plan a few different ways (read about 3 ways to meal plan here). Let me know in the comments your fun reasons for meal planning!

3-ways-for-busy-moms-to-meal-plan.name: 3-ways-for-busy-moms-to-meal-plan
3-ways-for-busy-moms-to-meal-plan.title: 3 Ways for Busy Moms to Meal Plan
3-ways-for-busy-moms-to-meal-plan.content:
I've recently realized all of the fun (heh) benefits to meal planning myself (read here to find out the 4 reasons busy moms should meal plan). I have gone through a few different meal planning strategies, and I've defaulted to different ways during different times in life. Here are three of my favorite ways to meal plan!

1.Trello

Trello is an organizational website and app. I use trello to create a board for the month, then create cards for each week and put the menu items we'd like to have under each week. Using this app I can also copy and paste any links to recipes I'd like to try out. I like that I can access it from wherever we are, and edit it as needed.

2.List to Online Order:

Another strategy, and also my most recent favorite, is to jot down a basic list to post on the fridge. Then I immediately open up my app for the grocery store pick up or delivery of choice (I've used Stop and Shop and Walmart in our area) and add the groceries meal by meal into my shopping cart. This is kind of like double duty. At that point I can either order the groceries for delivery or pick up the next day, or use my online "cart" as a list when I go to the store.

3.Sticky Note Planning-

I think it might be the teacher in me... but I love sticky notes. I always used them for planning when I was in the classroom full time... and I use them as a mom. I made a cute little sticky note template that I can use the small sticky notes on it. The thing I like about this template is that if you change your mind about what you'd like day by day, you can just shift the sticky notes around. I also cut off the bottom of my template and write my lists as soon as I'm done adding my sticky notes. Here's the template I use- Feel free to use it yourself as well (Just make sure you don't select fit to page when printing or else the sticky notes won't fit.).   Do you have any other fun ways to meal plan?

why-now-and-where-i-got-my-bravery.name: why-now-and-where-i-got-my-bravery
why-now-and-where-i-got-my-bravery.title: Why Now? And where I got my bravery
why-now-and-where-i-got-my-bravery.content: Lately I've been sharing things I never used to be comfortable with. I've been losing weight I never thought I could and talking to people I never felt worthy of talking to. I shared pictures of myself in my messy closet with just a tank and some leggings to track my weight loss progress... on Facebook. People I've worked with and whose children I've taught, and family members, and even sort of strangers saw these pictures. I went away with a bunch of ladies OVERNIGHT away from my kids and had a good time! I'm writing to you here on this blog... sharing the little and big things that are a part of my life after over 2 years of owning this site and just letting it sit. You're probably wondering...Why Now? And where on earth did I finally get the bravery? Something really sad happened to me. My grandfather died. He took his own life. Just a couple weeks before our annual family trip to go see him. I was angry, I was sad. I was at a standstill emotionally. How could he do this to my grandma? How was everyone supposed to pick up these pieces? I couldn't understand how everything he said he was so excited for was never going to happen. He prided himself in his great grandchildren knowing him, and he loved how they were telling all their friends how they had great grandparents. He wanted to watch them grow each year splashing away in his back yard pool... and now not only did we lose that chance... but now this is the memory he left his great grandchildren, grandchildren, children, wife, friends... all of us.  I was angry. Then I was sad. Sooo sooo sad. My grandpa had a sharp mind and years and years of story after story to tell over a nice glass of red wine late at night after we tucked the kids in on our visits. A part of that brilliant mind, I have now learned, was also too stubborn and strong to differentiate between the sad stories he was telling himself and the reality of all he had in this world. He felt that maybe people didn't love him and maybe didn't care about him for all sorts of random reasons. Or maybe he was getting old (he was only 72) and what if his best days were behind him.  And guess what?  None of this was freaking true! We all just loved him so much. We all knew there was no one else in this world just like him. He could have had many more amazing adventures on this earth. He wasn't listening to any of that, hearing it, or feeling it. I spent many (the days blurred together) quiet afternoons in my chair just thinking and trying to reason.  As I sat there it occurred to me that was sort of doing the same exact thing in my life...I was telling myself sad stories too and I wasn't even living a sad life. I was happy in my life and blessed with 3 beautiful children and a husband and a wonderful extended family. I was (and am still) bubbling over with gratefulness, but I also I felt guilt around every corner... I felt bad for working, I felt bad for leaving teaching. I felt bad for putting my kids to bed too late, and bad for not spending more time with them when I put them to bed early. I felt ashamed of my appearances and my weight, but bummed when I was a drag at a picnic because I was the one eating healthy. I was petrified of people stopping by my house because, if I'm being honest, it's always a disaster... but I often felt lonely and wished people would visit. I thought most people I talked to probably thought I was stupid and annoying, but also found myself sad if I sat alone and quiet.  And none of these sad stories are, or need to be freaking true either! And then something started happening within me in those very quiet and silent moments. I decided today is the day for all the things I'd been putting off. I decided I am strong enough to live this life the way it was meant to be lived. I am vowing to be a bright light in this world and to do everything I can to soak up every moment and smile and event in my life. To have the conversations, to give a disclaimer at the door ("Come in.. careful of the legos") instead of meeting people out on the front step. I've also decided to stop thinking of what people think of me because (as I've learned in some of the amazing books I've been reading) it's none of my business anyway.  Most importantly, it is time to stop having these strange sad narratives in my mind. Since I am an incurable "bright sider" I try to look for the bright side of every situation. In trying to make sense of all this I couldn't find any good in this situation, just sadness. There is no "good that grows" from a tragedy like this.  Since things will never be the same anyway,  why not use the power within myself to light up my own life (and hopefully the lives of some others)? I've decided to dream big and follow those dreams and do the things that make me happy, at peace, and be more of myself than ever before! It's not that I learned that life is short... it's that I learned that life is fragile and our minds and dreams are our own to shape... and from all of those feelings and decisions bravery grew.

comments.author: Wanda (Grandma) Grote
comments.content: ❤❤ it's not the way your house looks that matter...its the people inside that do..through this tragedy, we realize what truly is important and to make the very best out of life..no matter what..love this pic of you and Grandpa

5-books-every-mom-boss-should-read.name: 5-books-every-mom-boss-should-read
5-books-every-mom-boss-should-read.title: 5 Books Every Mom Boss Should Read
5-books-every-mom-boss-should-read.content:
Now that I've recently spilled my heart out on WHY I am on this journey, it makes the best sense to share how I am going through this journey! One of the ways I have been really learning and growing is through the books I've been reading. I have a confession: I've been reading "Self Help"  type books... and it feels so good! (*insert reader eye rolls*) I know, I know... I avoided these types of books like the plague for a VERY long time! I am not sure exactly why. I guess I wondered if they were a sham. Or tacky. Or corny. Or I was worried about what other people would think of me if I was spotted with any titles like this from across the room...  Well I am here to say that I am reading these books, loving them, and I won't apologize for it! These books, although some of the concepts were so new to me that they took warming up to, have opened my mind and reassured me that I do have the power I feel down in my gut to get things done and always move towards my best self living my best life! Here are 5 of my most recent favorite reads for moms who want to get things done and take back our lives! We shall call ourselves Mom Bosses... WingItMom Bosses. :-) Notice: These are affiliate links since I am a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for us to earn fees by linking to Amazon.com and affiliated sites. This is at no additional cost to you!
Girl, Wash Your Face: Stop Believing the Lies About Who You Are so You Can Become Who You Were Meant to Be I am currently in love with all things Rachel Hollis and the voice she gives real life, amazing moms like us! I also love how it's like she takes away the permission for us to continue to tell ourselves the lies that are holding us back! 2. Tales from the Crib: Adventures of an Over-sharing, Stressed-Out, Modern-Day Mom If you're looking for a real mom, who shares the funniest and messiest moments of motherhood, check out Deedee's book here! I know and love her as a person and author! 3. You Are a Badass: How to Stop Doubting Your Greatness and Start Living an Awesome Life This book is really where my perspective and mind starting to shift... and the thought entered my mind... "What if there is more than this..." Get ready for some brand new big ideas! 4. You Are a Badass at Making Money: Master the Mindset of Wealth This is the addition to the original book (number 3 above) and is a great way to extend your thinking when you consider what you think you deserve in this world! 5.Bossypants 1st edition by Fey, Tina (2011) Hardcover I love this book. It's a great book for any woman to read. And Tina Fey is hilarious! ... and I can't leave without one bonus book... Coming soon- Girl, Stop Apologizing: A Shame-Free Plan for Embracing and Achieving Your Goals I can suggest this one before it's release because if it's anything like Rachel Hollis' other work... we're in for a treat! If you are thinking... "How in the world am I supposed to find time to read?" I have to recommend Audible or another audio book platform. I often listen in the car, as I blog here to you... and as you know I even read and listen when putting my littlest one to bed! Find the little moments where you can grow in to the best, "baddassiest" WingItMom boss version of yourself! I'm always looking for new books to add to my list! Drop a list of your favorites in the comments!

favorite-clean-up-strategy.name: favorite-clean-up-strategy
favorite-clean-up-strategy.title: Favorite Clean Up Strategy
favorite-clean-up-strategy.content:
Since I've started this blog I've decided to let the cat out of the bag, it's no longer a secret, it's no longer something I'm trying to hide, it's  a full on admission... my house is a mess. No matter how many hours I spend cleaning, it's always a big fat mess! One thing I've struggled with having my kiddos help out in a way that actually helps... rather than just slows the whole process down! As my 10 year old grows, he is definitely more helpful in this department, but it doesn't mean he's always excited to do it!

Before we really get started...I just need to let you know that this post contains affiliate links since I am a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for us to earn fees by linking to Amazon.com and affiliated sites. This means if you click and buy, I may make a small commission at no additional cost to you!

Before employing this strategy I would often ask my kids to clean up the playroom which seemed like an insurmountable task to them, so I'd find myself delegating different tasks the whole time, getting frustrated by their distraction, and ultimately yelling, grounding them, and cleaning it myself. Enter Sticky Notes--- Have I mentioned how much I (and all kids I know) love them? I use them for meal planning, scheduling my work week, lesson planning, and especially for clean up time for my kids! We call it "Sticky Note Clean Up" And they actually ask me to set them up with it now... unprompted! The prep for it involves taking a quick glance at the room, writing a category of mess on each sticky note, and then sticking it to the wall. Sometimes I use a different sticky note color for each child, and other times I just stick them all up there. Either way, this helps to keep them guided as they clean, feel like they are accomplishing completing the task, and keeps them out of my hair. Here's a sample of my clean up wall! Now here's a little extra tip! 10 item (or 5 item, or 20 item depending on the scale of the mess) clean up is one of my favorites. It involves picking any 10 items from the floor and putting them where they belong. It's a great way to cover all the random stuff under there! So break out those sticky notes, list out the chores, and put those kiddos to work! Use different colors, shapes and sizes to keep them interested time after time! Share your "Sticky Note Clean Up" walls on my facebook page... Bonus points for before/after pictures!

design-the-life-you-love.name: design-the-life-you-love
design-the-life-you-love.title: Design the Life You Love
design-the-life-you-love.content:
It's a new month! Whether you're reading this on the date it's released, or any random date in the future... you're finding this post just in the right time for you! I have lately been really thinking hard on what is in my heart that I am trying to put into words and this quote totally sums it up for me:

"She designed a life she loved."

I am head over heals in love with this quote because... 1.It reminds me that I am in charge of designing my life, not just experiencing it as a backseat passenger (or worse... a backseat driver)... and that means YOU are in charge of designing your life too! This reason is all about taking my power back! 2. It helps me to get into action. After all, when I picture my best life, I have some crazy action to get into! 3. The quote is in past tense... forcing me to visualize and picture the time when I'm there... living my best life! It helps to shape my reality! (If you haven't taken a minute to close your eyes and dream big dreams yet.... do it now!) This new perspective is definitely inspired by the awesome books I've been reading, but also most recently, the Last 90 Day Challenge organized by Rachel Hollis!  It's all about embracing and really continuing momentum of positive change through the end of the year, instead of slipping backward. You can join her challenge on her page here (It's totally free and she's amazing). In order to help me design my life, I'm following her 5 To Thrive which involve really setting and sticking to 5 daily goals (The specifics will come in your welcome e-mail if you sign up), and I need a little bit of guidance when sitting down and making this progress. I decided to create my own journal to help guide me! I'll share it with you here if you'd like to check it out and start designing your own life!

christmas-family-traditions.name: christmas-family-traditions
christmas-family-traditions.title: 5 Favorite Family Christmas Traditions
christmas-family-traditions.content:
I hope everyone had a super holiday season. It was such a whirlwind that I haven't had a moment to stop and write about it.  The interesting thing I also have to admit is... I forgot the password to login to my blog, and finally figured out how to get back in (Hey, I promised to be real with you). I always think it's so fun to share and hear about holiday traditions different families have developed each year. It was always one of my favorite assignments to give my class because I loved seeing the pictures and seeing their eyes light up with excitement. When I was little,  I most remember going to my aunts house every Christmas Eve. It was my favorite tradition. My great grandma would usually send all the kids Chrsitmas jammies and we'd play with our cousins, binge on soda and sweets, and open a present. I remember the car ride home at night, looking out the window at the sky just hoping and hoping I'd catch a glimpse of Santas sleigh. Ok, can you tell this memory makes me feel totally nostalgic?) As I've grown up and am the mom to our party of 5, here are some traditions I've come to love:

1.Black Friday Shopping-

Each holiday season my mom and I head out to brave the cold Thanskgiving night, coffee in hand and pie in our bellies. We browse around mostly these days, since we do most of our shopping online, but there is still something special about that black Friday shopping feeling for me.

2. Christmas lights-

This tradition started when I was little, and has grown as I have a family of my own. Every year we pick a night to all get in our jammies, make cocoa in our Mickey Mouse travel mugs from trips to Disney past, and drive around to check out the Christmas lights in our town. We have a few really awesome and beautiful homes who synchronize their lights to music.  

3. Gingerbread Houses-

For the past several years (more than 10 I think), we have had my sisters over to make gingerbread houses with my kids. I am both untalented and a cheapskate, so we only decorate the small gingerbread village ones each year. Years ago my younger sisters were kids, so it was perfect. Of course as time has gone by one is an adult and one is a junior in high school and they still come to decorate gingerbread houses. This year, we had dinner and cake for my brother's birthday, which is in December, and then everyone (even all the grown ups) decorated.

4. Decorating the tree-

This tradition is evolving. We have an artificial tree, and typically we have set it up the weekend after Thanksgiving, however the past couple years have been an exception. This past Thanksgiving we were traveling for my grandfathers service, and the year before we were on vacation, but regardless, It's always fun to have the kids put up their handmade ornaments from years past. We actually got a new bigger tree for our living room this year and made that one a little more basic/traditional, and we set up our smaller tree with handmade ornaments in the dining room next to our fake fireplace (listen I go for low maintenance all the way around). (PS... Can you tell exactly how tall Ellie is? At almost 2, she was more into undecorating the tree than decorating it)  

5. Extended Family Get together-

  This is like the new version of my favorite childhood memory... The weekend before Christmas I had my extended family over. It fills my heart to fill my home with aunts, uncles, cousins, cousins kids.  More than 40 people spilled in on Saturday night, followed by my grandmas homemade mac and cheese, my dads cheesy potatoes, one aunt's famous meatballs, another aunt's delicious pasta salad, and yet another aunt's gourmet cheese platter. We had corn casserole (this was delish... I have never tasted anything like it), salad and cookies... lots and lots of cookies. Years ago we used to do what we called a "Yankee Swap". All the grown ups brought a gift valued at a certain amount and we'd play a fun game to end up with a random surprise gift. It was super fun, but it was also difficult to find great gifts over the years, and the tradition sort of petered out over time. Instead, now we do a cookie swap. Everyone brings a couple types of cookies they like to make, and we shop it like a wonderful cookie buffet and fill our trays with a variety of Christmas cookies.   These are just a few ways we get into the Christmas spirit, in addition to the gingerbread lattes, random Christmas carol dance parties, and a whole slew of Christmas movies that also sprinkle the Christmas season for us. What are some of your favorite holiday traditions?

very-merry-sickmas.name: very-merry-sickmas
very-merry-sickmas.title: Very Merry "Sick"mas
very-merry-sickmas.content: In true "wing it mom" fashion our Christmas ended up being full of unexpected twists and turns.  You guys... I felt like I was in one of those bad holiday movies where you think "All those things cannot possibly happen to one family" Let's rewind to Saturday December 22. We had our big family get together and it was a great time, although in hindsight I suspect there were some germs floating around there due to the events that would unfold over the next 72 hours. My middle kiddo does have pretty yucky asthma though, and of course he had woken up Saturday morning with one of his "rough coughs" which typically indicate an impending asthma attack which lands us in the hospital. I called the pulmonologist and we started him on some steroids to try to avoid another (yes another) hospital visit near Christmas time this year. Luckily, he perked up quite a bit (too much even with the steroid he was quite full of it). Sunday felt like  day where we were trying to just make the time pass. We were all prepared for Christmas (or so we thought) and we just were excitedly waiting for Christmas Eve when we get together with my parents and siblings. We played games all day and watched A Christmas Story. It really was a nice low key day. I tucked my kiddos in excited myself that the very next night Santa would be coming... and then... it happened. At 4:00 am Carter was up crying that his stomach hurt and he was so hungry. I gave him a granola bar and sent him to bed, thinking that this was probably the side effect of 2 days worth of steroids... but then it really happened... Our little Ellie woke up and instantly threw up all over our bed (don't judge... sometimes she sleeps in the middle). Then she acted fine... We hoped it was a fluke... until I heard Carter cry "MOM!" and I knew... he had thrown up too. After cleaning up I got right into the car and drove to the store. We had no gatorade, no tylenol, no basic saltine crackers... I was not prepared to wing it.  Halfway through my very quick store trip my stomach began to gurgle. As you can imagine, without anymore detail it was a miserable Christmas Eve. the 3 of us were so very sick the whole day. Luckily, by morning we were feeling a lot better (but not 100%). Thankfully we were able to catch some smiles for opening presents and it was a good morning! Let's talk about what unfolded next... At around 4pm, our oldest, RJ began to complain of his stomach. I knew what was coming (we had been bracing ourselves). Within an hour of the start of his sickness, Carter began to have a pretty bad asthma attack. We just couldn't get it under control, so I ended up taking him to the Emergency Room, which is where we spend Christmas evening (He ended up being diagnosed with pneumonia the next day by the pediatrician, which is a pretty terrible diagnosis for an asthmatic kiddo.)... So let's just summarize this... within an hour I had one child begin a terrible sickness and he couldn't even move off the couch and I had another one who needed to be rushed to the emergency room. My heart was torn in half. How in the world do you leave either one? There was so much disappointment, the "canceling" of our typical Christmas Eve, and then the rescheduling of RJ's birthday sleepover which was scheduled for just 2 days later (we are NOT the kind of people who try to spread germs on purpose) Thankfully, in true wing it mom fashion- I promised the kids we would reschedule Christmas Eve, and we did just that! Friday evening we carried on the entire day like it was Christmas Eve. We decorated our sugar cookies, we played Christmas music, and we went to my parents' house for dinner and to exchange gifts. It did feel like Christmas thankfully! Ironically, through all of our precaution and waiting, we STILL somehow mentioned to get my entire family sick more than 3 days after we had been sick. This was just a tough bug I guess. It was definitely a year where we dug deep and held onto our gratitude for all we have to celebrate that things could be worse. At least we were able to be together. Christmas 2018 has been officially dubbed a Very Merry Sickmas.

5-favorite-christmas-cookie-recipes.name: 5-favorite-christmas-cookie-recipes
5-favorite-christmas-cookie-recipes.title: 5 Favorite Christmas Cookie Recipes
5-favorite-christmas-cookie-recipes.content: Christmas is my favorite time of year! In fact I've had a whole list of Christmas posts to share with you, which have been stuck on my todo list for quite some time! One of my favorite things to do is to bake cookies! One of the reasons is probably that we avoid sweets the rest of the year, but we give into the holiday time of year and eat all the yummy things! Here are 5 of my favorite cookie recipes for Christmas time. I LOVE these sugar cookies! They hold their shape, they are perfectly balanced in flavor and they are soft. I actually make these throughout the year whenever there is an event, I just pick a differently shaped cookie cutter and voila! Here's a link to the recipe I use. If you are wondering how I found this recipe... it was by googling "Best Sugar Cookie Recipe"... and I think the results were pretty accurate this time Google! Chocolate Mint Cookies I am a true mint cookie lover. This recipe I avoided for a while because it involved melting chocolate and chilling the dough, however, now that I've made them, they are definitely a favorite and one my kiddos (and other family members) scold me for skipping if I try. Here's a link to the recipe I use! Chocolate Dipped Oreos This cookie doesn't even need a recipe! This year I just bought a pack of regular and a pack of mint oreos (I told ya, I love mint), and a couple cups of microwavable baker chocolate. I melted the chocolate, dipped the oreos and sprinkled them with whatever sprinkles I wanted! The only thing I have tried that doesn't work well is the sugar crystal sprinkles. Otherwise it's super easy, no baking required and they look pretty fancy! Peanut Butter Blossoms Here's another "Great for anytime" type of recipe. Peanut butter blossom cookies are a definite favorite. My brother and sister in law make a delicious peanut butter chocolate chip cookie, and one of the two I think will be required at any future get together. It is just the perfect combo. Here's the recipe I use! Pillsbury Sugar Cookies This may seem like a cheat... but...I am a sucker for good old fashioned pillsbury store bought sugar cookie dough. It's the kind I grew up on and is the only way to make cookies for Santa. Roll out the dough and cover them obnoxiously with all the sprinkles.  The only recipe instruction I have is that... I love them barely cooked and chewy. yummm. The kids are always in charge of making these cookies and it's become a very delicious tradition.   Here are some honorable mentions which we also love: Andes Mint Surprise Cookies  Hershey Kisses Chocolate Chip Cookies Easy Shortbread Cookies

fun-penguin-activities-for-toddlers-and-.name: fun-penguin-activities-for-toddlers-and-preschoolers
fun-penguin-activities-for-toddlers-and-.title: Fun Penguin Activities for Toddlers and Preschoolers
fun-penguin-activities-for-toddlers-and-.content:
We've been so excited to keep going with our fun thematic kind of "play at home" activities. This week we're full into winter fun with reading and playing all about penguins! I always like to incorporate a bunch of different activities even if they are really "too hard" for my daughter. I see a huge value in her exposure to the activities even if she's watching me model the activities or doing some sort of variation of the activities. This week we read a few informational books about penguins. Sometimes I read all the text, and sometimes I pull out the vocabulary and we point to the pictures. I don't ever really wash down the vocabulary, even if it does seem "above her head". It's really one of the best ways to increase background knowledge and vocabulary acquisition, which is essential to early literacy development. Here are the informational books we read this week.   We learned that penguins like to eat fish! So we pulled out our first activity

1.Penguin Paths

This is basically a multi-use map, which is why I decided to laminate it (with my brand new laminator which is AMAZING by the way). There are so many ways to use these mats, we decided to trace them with our fingers, I held her hand and she traced, and then we lined the gems up along the lines together (be careful to supervise, because these are choking hazards). You could also make playdough snakes, trace with a dry erase marker, place pom poms or a number of other materials onto these mats. I made mine double sided with two different "levels" of lines. When we did the activity together, she started by pushing the gems one at a time, but then ultimately filled up the entire mat and said she was "all done". Totally fine (and expected) for a 23 month old! As you go through your play at home learning, just wing it!

2.Peekaboo Penguin

One of the books talked about how penguins come from eggs, so we made our own peekaboo penguin. She colored the penguin and I cut out the egg. Then we attached it to a popsicle stick and could make the penguin pop out of the egg. This is a really fun way to begin the learning about life cycles with really young kids!  

4. Penguins on Ice!

For this activity we practiced counting! I placed the numbers 1-5 on sticky notes and put it on each plate. We looked over the penguin counters (they are all different kinds of penguins) and talked about all the penguins. She loved the ones with little eyebrows. Then we counted them out onto the different paper plates (icebergs).  Again, it's totally fine if your little one doesn't know how to count yet! Ellie is great at recited counting and can point and count up to 3, but she is still working on this skill. Even just having her place the penguins on the paper plate is a great activity. In this particular activity she asked for glue right away. So we ended up gluing the penguins on the plate (for the numbers 1,2, and 3 but then she was done gluing). I attached the numbers to the back of the plates so shes having fun this week just flipping them over and pointing at the penguins.  

5.Dress Me Up Penguin

We also decided to do a penguin dress up. This was perfect as a follow up for reading Tacky the Penguin. We colored in the pieces and then she got to choose how to dress up her penguins.   You could also laminate these pieces and attach some velcro pieces to the big penguin and to the backs of the clothing pieces. You could also do the same with magnets and attach the penguin to a cookie sheet with magnets on the back of each of the pieces.  

6.Penguin or Polar Bear?

On two separate paper plates, I placed the sorting pieces for polar bear and penguins. Then we sorted the polar bears onto one plate and penguins onto another.  We'll definitely do this again next week when we play all about polar bears.

7. Paper Plate Penguin

Paint the back of a paper plate black (As you can see our old black paint is suffering and dried a shade of grayish purple... oh well!). Then fold the sides in, top down, and have your little one add eyes/ googly eyes and a beak. You can also add feet, but she was all done, so we left it at these. I applied the paperclips just so the glue could dry to hold the top of the paper plate face down.

8. Penguin Stories:

We have a few fun penguin stories here at home, but also have borrowed from the library, or even utilized online read aloud videos to listen to some stories! Here are some links to our favorites:     If you'd like to use these resources with you kiddo(s) you can get the PDF version here:

ten-tips-for-long-trips-with-kids.name: ten-tips-for-long-trips-with-kids
ten-tips-for-long-trips-with-kids.title: Ten Tips for Long Trips with Kids
ten-tips-for-long-trips-with-kids.content:
Since my grandparents moved to Myrtle Beach, we've been making annual (or sometimes twice a year) trips to visit them.  We've driven to Florida a few times too. My kids are at the point where an hour and a half drive is "super short".  When we first started our trips we were a family of four, and now we're a family of 5 with an almost 2 year old. During our most recent drive to travel to my grandfathers funeral service, I began to think about all the ways we had sort of planned and deliberately made some choices which would help us wing it when we needed to, and help us avoid winging it when we didn't. So here they are... my list  of:

10 Tips for Long Trips with Kids

1. Drowsy Driving (for the kids of course)

If you're trip of exceptionally long and you will be traveling for most of the daylight hours, leave when your kids are still drowsy. Sometimes an interrupted sleep schedule will work to your advantage in the form of extra naps along the way. For us we leave between 3am - 4:30am. I have friends who leave at bedtime and drive while the kids sleep. I suppose this would maybe work for us if I could keep my eyes open past 8pm... and if we didn't have 3 little ones to care for once we arrived who would be well rested and ready to play while we hadn't caught any zzzzzzz.

2.  Love Your Lunchbox

Pack your kids(and yourself) a lunch and/or dinner in a lunch box  along with a variety of "rations" (snacks).  We used to just plan to stop along the way. During the year we usually don't visit fast food joints often, so our drive down was always the exception, however, we found that they hadn't really grown that fond of rest stop food. Packing lunches helps us to eat when we are hungry, and then grab an extra small fry on the ride if we're in the mood. Rationing out small snacks is also a great way to keep them busy throughout the ride as well.

3.Border Bags

When we first started traveling I was looking for ways to help "reward" the kids for their patience as well as keep them busy, so I came across the idea of giving kids something for each hour of the trip. Instead of this, I decided to put together paper baggies with goodies in them labeled with each state. I would alternate snacks, sometimes a movie, a little toy or one of the $3 or $4 small lego set etc. This helps them to witness/ experience the progress and are also great for learning about the different states they will pass through geographically on their way. This past time the older kids had tons of video games etc. and they really didn't need anything extra for the trip, so we filled plastic eggs with undisclosed amounts of cash. They got to pick an egg at each state. I think there was a total of like $7 for each of them, but they were excited to have a little cash to use at one of those rest stop candy or sticker machines.

4. The need for rest stops is real

When I was growing up our rest stops were always sparse. The name of the game was getting to our destination as quickly as possible. This, however, always caused me to be afraid to drink during the ride, for fear of needing to go #1 when a rest stop was still hours away. When we decided to travel, the first promise we made was to stop when someone needed a rest stop. Make it quick if it's just for the bathroom, and if you need a break and a stretch, take it slowly and take the 10-15 minutes to recharge. Speaking of rest stops- also always try to estimate rest stop time into your ETA... your big kids are counting down the time and they will hold you to it.  We always add a solid 3 hours to our GPS time when we have a 12 hour drive. They never complain if you arrive early.

5. Don't Forget Flip Flops

Regardless of the season, bring flip flops for everyone, especially the kids. First of all, if you plan to visit a pool when you get where you're going, you'll have to bring them anyway.  For the drive, however, these are great for quick run ins to rest stops. I can't even tell you the amount of time we've spent shaking out blankets and pillows and digging through piles of crayons, markers, and video games to try to find socks and shoes buried beneath the ruins they'd been working on for the past 3 hours. If you're anti flip flop, then have them take off their shoes right when they get into the car and pack an extra pair of socks somewhere handy so you can get to them quickly at rest stops.

6.Forget your screen time limits.

We set screen time limits for our kids, and it works great during the regular routines of our household, however, when it's a long drive like this, bring out the Ipad, DS, Movies etc. You are in survival mode.

7. Keep essentials handy

I can't tell you the number of times that we've accidentally thrown the bag with the dramamine and motrin in the trunk, which calls for a stop if someone needs something along the trip. Instead we now plan for motion sickness (keep dramamine, peppermint essential oils and beadlets, plastic bags and paper towels) handy.  After this last trip, I'll also always pack some stinky spray with my favorite essential oils).We also make sure water and our other daily meds are within reach since we leave so early in the morning and don't usually take them until we're on the road.

8. If you're traveling with a pacifier kid- bring extras!

Not one extra... like 2 or 3 extra.  In our experience, the pacifiers are used as an emotional warfare weapon against parents on the drive. When she doesn't want to be in the car anymore, she'll toss the pacifier "overboard" (meaning to the side of the car that no one can reach while we're driving). We always keep a few extra ones handy because once she's done tantruming she often wants a pacifier to calm down and we have a nice one handy.

9. Cups with Lids

For our older kiddos we like to bring a travel mug with a straw in addition to their water bottles. This way we can put milk, juice or gingerale/gatorade (for sore tummys) with less of a chance of spills.  If you have a real little one, fill one sippy cup with whatever they usually drink, but bring an extra one to keep handy too!  Our littlest drinks milk in the morning, and it's not always convenient to rinse it out when we want to switch her over to water for the day.

10. When all else fails, resort to bribery- your greatest wing-it-mom-weapon

Especially if you are like me and do not regularly engage in bribing your children, they perk right up and listen when they hear one fly out there.  Ice cream when we get there... a donut at dunkin....5 bucks... whatever it takes. And if you're interested in doing a few simple things to keep your own sanity... here are 2 bonus tips because when mama ain't happy... ain't nobody happy! * Treat yo'self - when you are packing your kids' lunches, don't forget to pack for you....and throw in some chocolate and salty chips, and gummy worms...and don't forget to stop at starbucks for that gingerbread ice latte that you love, the extra time added to your trip for that stop will be worth it. * Get intellectual with your navigator and listen while they read a book. If you are flying solo listen to an audiobook. Don't forget to pause and discuss newly gained knowledge. Here are a couple of the latest books we read Crucial Conversations and https://cliffordoravec.com/the-epic-guide-to-bootstrapping-a-startup and I even forced my family to listen to the audio book version of Becoming by Michelle Obama.

favorite-homemade-playdough-recipe.name: favorite-homemade-playdough-recipe
favorite-homemade-playdough-recipe.title: Favorite Homemade Playdough recipe
favorite-homemade-playdough-recipe.content:
We absolutely LOVE making playdough around here! We worked together to perfect a wonderful recipe that last and lasts for us.

I like that it's not too oily and it's not too sticky. We add all sorts of things to our playdough to snazz it up. Here's our basic recipe.

(Includes affiliate links)

1 Cup flour

1/2 Cup Salt

1 1/2 Tablespoons Cream Of Tartar

1 1/2 Tablespoons Veggie oil

1 Cup water

Put it all in a saucepan, let the pan heat up and then stir. Keep on stirring and trust the process! It will form a nice ball of dough.  You can add your food coloring at the beginning as well, as long as things like cinnamon. If I am adding glitter I always wait until it's cooled down quite a bit and then I knead the glitter in.

 

This recipe lasts months... although we make different versions so often it doesn't need to. I usually just store it in a Ziploc Gallon Storage Bags.

 

We've been on the hunt for a great no- cook recipe, so if you have one handy, please pass it along!

the-most-important-question-we-ask-our-k.name: the-most-important-question-we-ask-our-kids
the-most-important-question-we-ask-our-k.title: The Most Important Question We Ask Our Kids
the-most-important-question-we-ask-our-k.content:
It's 6:45 am and my phone starts to buzz and remind me that it's time to get the kiddos up and break the silence in the house. I take a longing look at my cup of coffee, knowing that whatever remains in my cup will cool and me microwaved probably 12 times before I finally give up and pour it down the drain because the hustle and bustle of the morning is about to begin.

... Ok , you caught me. The scenario I painted is truth about twice a week. The rest of the time my alarm wakes me up after hitting the snooze button 3 times and causes me to begrudgingly slide out of bed.

Whether I wake up with them or before them, I love to take a few minutes to breathe in a big hug, say good morning, and ask an important question. It's a question that sounds sort of silly because of the way we've made it a tradition of asking. It's a question that helps us to manage our expectations, help one another, and approach the day with purpose and positivity.

The question is..."What's your best day?"

I know, it's not the clearest asked question, but it's the way we've chosen to ask it. No matter how you ask the question, the meaning behind it is the same. "What would the best version of today look like."

In these morning time conversations we're not talking about great big dreams (we save those conversations for other times, but we still do have those talks too). These convos are about the day before us. Knowing the schedule, the obligations of the day, and our own desires, we talk out the best day. Since I am a huge advocate of winging it, this does NOT always mean making a detailed plan.

The conversation often sounds like this:

Me- "Hey buddy. Morning! (insert big hug). So it's Monday. What's your best day?"

Kid- "hmm. Cheerios for breakfast, a calm day at school, and probably some drawing in the afternoon. What's your best day?"

Me- "My best day is... talking to grandma a bit on the phone, doing a little bit of work, playing with Ellie, and snuggling with each of you for a little while tonight."

This quick check in conversation helps us to set some basic goals for the day, and also helps us to understand what each other's goals are. It also helps us to feel a sense of peace and accomplishment about the day.

It's so simple, it's so basic, but I know each time we chat about this I have a pulse on what matters to my kids. Sometimes their best day includes hoping their friend is back to school after being sick for a day or two. Sometimes it's finishing a school project... and some snowy days its hanging out in PJS, playing a family game, and binge watching the office. I feel like it keeps us connected, and as a mom it helps me to sort of plan a bit and to know what to expect. For example... when my 7 year old has rock painting on his mind. I kind of prepare myself for that messy afternoon crafty time.

Do things happen during the day that are NOT part of our best days? YES! Do we sometimes skip out on things that we intended to do? Yes! But we roll with it!

At the beginning we definitely had lots and lots of things on our best day list, but we've gotten pretty good at narrowing it down. Even our two year old is getting super great at telling something she wants to do during the day as their best day.

Do we always every day without fail ask this question in the morning? Heck no. We are human. Sometimes time slips away. Sometimes someone's sick. And sometimes we don't check in until the afternoon when they get off the bus, but the cool thing is that often times even if we haven't said it out loud, we are still all thinking about having our best day!

I think the key is that we're approaching our days with intention and the belief that today will be the best version of today.

So... what's your best day? Let me know!

the-a-word-and-why-it-sucks.name: the-a-word-and-why-it-sucks
the-a-word-and-why-it-sucks.title: The A Word. And Why it Sucks
the-a-word-and-why-it-sucks.content:
There are times in this life when I am totally great at winging it. Then there are times when my kids are sick and the winging it that comes along with those times makes me feel all crumpled up inside.

This morning I found myself "winging it" when I had a day scheduled out and was awoken in the wee hours of the morning by a kiddo who is totally sick. Instead of the leisurely stroll through the grocery store I had planned, I rushed through, forgot half of my items, and made it home just in time to bring him to the doctor ( Yes our doctor is amazing and met us at the office to check him out on a Saturday morning).

Ok call me a worry wart. Call me a nervous nelly. Call me neurotic... but when any my kids are sick I worry. And when my middle kiddo is sick... I sit around on edge like a ball of nerves.

No, it's not because I play favorites. It's because he has the a word... asthma. Like really crappy sucky asthma. So sucky that it's become like a swear word in our house...

To give a little context, let's pause and rewind back 5 years ago. Here's what I "knew" about asthma. My brother had asthma as a kid and sometimes when he ran around he needed an inhaler. I had read about kids dying of asthma and I imagined they didn't have their inhalers on hand or maybe they were alone and couldn't get help.

Then, 4 years and 10 months ago, when my middle kiddo was 2 1/2, he was diagnosed with asthma. I'll save his dramatic diagnosis story for another day, but let's just say we brought him to the ER thinking maybe he needed an inhaler and we were told that he was having a life threatening asthma attack and they hoped that the medicines would work. Scariest. Words. Ever.

Since that day we've had numerous ambulance rides and emergency room visits. It's been a crazy scary journey because... breathing is kind of an important thing.

Anyway being an asthma mom has come to mean jumping out of bed when I hear the "rough coughs" that sound like the beginning of something scary. I've purchased pulse oximeter just to be reassured that his body is getting the oxygen it needs. I'm paranoid of the coughs and sniffles of strangers because every runny nose can turn into a scary situation, sometimes before we even know he is sick. And right now as I write to you, I'm the mom who is curled up next to my 7 year old, wrapped up in a blanket after a breathing treatment obsessively checking his O2 sat as he dozes and fevers. And as soon as I am sure that he's ok, I'll sneak away and pack a hospital bag, just like I do every time I hear a cough or sneeze because things can change and go downhill so quickly.

I am not writing this to get sympathy (for myself or my kiddo) although maybe sometimes we are deserving. I'm really writing this because I didn't know how scary asthma could be until I saw it in my own child. I've seen eye rolls of colleagues and family members when I stayed home from work to monitor his breathing. I've heard comments like "doesn't he have an inhaler?" from friends who just didn't know how serious asthma could be. I've felt like teachers and the school nurse probably think I'm just one of those parents who keeps their kids out of school for every little sniffle. So I figured it's worth a shot to share out into this world how much asthma sucks. Anyways, we all need a good vent session now and then.

For now, I'll be returning to my crumpled up state for the next several hours (hopefully not days) as we wait out this yucky bug, hoping we can stay home and not rush to the emergency room like so many times before because like I said before... Asthma sucks.

5-gifts-for-busy-moms.name: 5-gifts-for-busy-moms
5-gifts-for-busy-moms.title: 5 Gifts for Busy Moms
5-gifts-for-busy-moms.content:
So it's that time of year again... this year I'm 33... and 3 is my lucky number, so is 33 doubly lucky? I sure hope so! I got a few really awesome birthday gifts that I thought were absolutely PERFECT for "Wing It Moms" like us... and that got me thinking... What are some great gifts to give to a busy mom?

Here are the 5 ideas I'm loving most!

(This post contains affiliate links. I am a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for us to earn fees by linking to Amazon.com and affiliated sites.)

1. Seasonal coffee mug

Having a coffee mug (or multiple!) that match the season spark me some major joy in the morning. I feel like if I start my day with a coffee cup I love, the day's going to be a great one.  I'm a huge Christmas fan, so I have a few of those, but I got to thinking that I didn't really have a springtime mug as the weather warmed up. Thanks to my awesome sisters, I have a new springy mug and tons of caffeinated beverages to fill it with!

2. Audible Gift Membership

I LOVE to listen to books, since I hardly have time to sit down and look at them. Listening to audiobooks is one of my favorite things to do when I'm cleaning, working, or sick of listening to the Peppa Pig marathon on TV. I especially love it when the author reads the book. (I just finished Girl, Stop Apologizing and now I'm onto IMomSoHard).

 

3.  Pamper Session 

Whether the mom in your life loves manicures, pedicures, massages, facials, or a day at the spa... it's perfect to get a certificate to do one of these things for ourselves. It's almost like a ticket with permission to take care of ourselves (not that we should need it)! This year my mom and I went to get pedicures the morning of my birthday. Of course when I got home, my little gal had to get herself some pink toes too!

4. Cricut

My husband got me a Cricut Explore Air 2 this year for my birthday and I. AM. IN. LOVE! It can do so many amazing things. I've used it to make fun sayings to place on the walls around the house. Made myself a new coffee mug (I'm still learning hehe), and even made a birthday tag for a party I forgot to buy a card for. It's just amazing!

5. TILE 

This had to be my big finale. This year my mom got this for me and it's about time I had something to help me manage my habit of constantly losing things over and over again. It was quite appropriate coming from her, since I almost always lose my keys somewhere around her house every time I am over. This TILE system is awesome! I downloaded an app on my phone, synced my tiles, and now all I have to do is open the app and select to find my keys and they start chiming! The best part... it works in reverse too! If I have my keys but can't find my phone, I click the bucket on my Tile and my phone starts to ring! Absolutely a game changer! (Here's a link to the one I got! Tile Mate and Slim Combo Pack)

 

6. Roborox (or some sort of vacuuming robot)

 

Ok I know I said that this was going to be a list of 5... but this gift has been truly life changing. As an early anniversary gift, my husband bought this Roborock S5 Robotic Vacuum and Mop Cleaner. You guys... we have a robot! This thing is awesome! We tidy the floor and off to work it goes! Here's a short video of how awesome it is (and yes that is a heaping basket of clean clothes in the background...)

completely-frozen-winter-themed-birthday.name: completely-frozen-winter-themed-birthday-party
completely-frozen-winter-themed-birthday.title: Completely Frozen Winter Themed Birthday Party
completely-frozen-winter-themed-birthday.content:
Our little toddler turned two this past week and she just had to have an "Elsie" party (of course that's just her insanely cute way of saying "Elsa").  Frozen has been a favorite of hers for a long time, so it made sense to run with the winter wonderland theme if we could! I am not usually a huge fan of commercial character birthday themes. I've most enjoyed themes like The Very Hungry Caterpillar (ok that's a little commercial), Valentine's Day Brunch, scientist, magic, and carnival themed parties.  So... when it came time to plan for this party I knew that we wouldn't be purchasing the plastic tablecloths adorned with Elsa and Anna, although she would have probably loved them!  This time, also as a part of our mission to be a little more environmentally friendly, we purchased cloth tablecloths for the food tables that we can just wash and reuse party after party. The other super special thing was that my awesome friend Tara from Mystic Roots Signs made Ellie this super cute snow themed shirt! It was themed but still classy and we absolutely loved the play on the TWO with the snowflake! When you plan a party, there are a few different things to think about:

Food

This was one of our biggest challenges. Once I pick a theme I struggle and mull over ways to connect it back to our theme somehow. After much searching and chatting with friends... tossing ideas around... here are the snacks, main dishes, and desserts we came up with! We had frozen themed snacks from a snowy day dip, to cold cut sandwiches! I put the snacks out in the main living room, and we put all the lunch foods in the dining room. Snacks: Snowman/ Olaf noses- Cheese puffs Snowballs-  Smartfood Cheddar Popcorn Snow Day Chips and Dip- Sven Snacks Olaf Arms Lunch Items: *Cold Cut Sandwiches *Chilly *Snow Day Pasta Salad *Ice Berg Salad *Snow Covered Salad *Snowman Sandwiches

Decorations

We stuck with blue and white snowflake theme. I got a sheet of blue glitter tulle to lay on top of the white tablecloth on the cake/dessert table to make it extra fancy! We also got  balloon sticks because the party store near us was having some sort of helium issue. I just put the balloon sticks in glasses from the dollar store with those little gems inside (which we've even used during our penguin and polar bear learning weeks).  I like this idea because a little baggie of balloons is cheap and we put these away to reuse for future parties! At the last minute I got this white Wilton cupcake stand. I got some glitter cardstock and cut one inch strips of paper and attached it around the cupcake holder. After Christmas I got some of these little clear snowflakes at the dollar store for 1/2 off. I just hot glued one on the front. I used leftover materials for the utensil holder for the food table as well. We also got some cute little hangy snowflake twirly things for the ceiling which made her very happy. We put those in the living room and kitchen area where the activities were. One of my favorite parts of the decoration process was the tags that were really a part of labeling the food.
